H0.text: Prophase I is the phase during which the nuclear envelope begins to break down.

H1.text: Nitrogenase i is the phase during which the nuclear envelope begins to break down.

H2.text: Pasiphaë I is the phase during which the nuclear envelope begins to break down.

H3.text: Interphase is the phase during which the nuclear envelope begins to break down.

A4.text: The nuclear envelope stays intact during this process.

A5.text: the meiotic prophase ends with the spindle apparatus beginning to form, and the nuclear membrane beginning to break down

A6.text: In fungi, chromosomes divide within an intact cell nucleus during mitosis.

A7.text: In animal cells, the nuclear envelope breaks down before chromosome separation during mitosis.

A8.text: In other eukaryotes (animals as well as plants), the nuclear membrane must break down during the prometaphase stage of mitosis to allow the mitotic spindle fibers to access the chromosomes inside.
